column1: Will Nicolas Maduro cease to be president of Venezuela before 1 April 2021?
column6: ['Foreign Policy', 'Leader Entry/Exit', 'Non-US Politics']

IT is now March 30th and Nicolas Maduro is still president of Venezuela, it is therefore very very unlikely for the President to cease power in the upcoming days. IT will be April 1st on Thursday, it is Tuesday, there is nothing to prompt the president to resign or cease power, he will continue to hold power until the foreseeable future.
With just couple of days to go before the deadline, the chances in the form of coup attempt or voluntary stepdown looks very slim.
Weak international policies and supportive USA.
No change
Unlikely in this week
This forecast is the time update he still in power
Very little time left for this to occur at this point. Reducing.
Heard news there is a Maduro and Guaido cooperation with vaccines. , , ,
I'd love to see rationale from anyone who doesn't have 0 at this point other than "there is always some possibility therefore 0 is illogical" 👀
Nothing new coming out of Venezuela and we're only 2 weeks out. Reducing to zero.
Just because I haven't updated this in a while. Almost there, still not seeing any chance.
Bringing this down to 0% since we are two week out.
applied same powerlaw as for the Tigray-question: 98.9%
Venezuela's Maduro receives first dose of Sputnik V coronavirus vaccine - Reuters https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-venezuela-idUSKBN2AY0IC Sat, 06 Mar 2021 16:08:00 GMT

No. The Parliament in place seems to currently side with Maduro. Maduro is wanted by the DEA and there are US arrest for drug and weapons trafficking. It is doubtful Maduro will travel to the US, allied country with extradition agreements or enter the US embassy. There does not appear to be any more elections in the near future, Maduro’s political party, the United Socialist Party of Venezuela won 67% of the seat in the National Assembly in December 2020. There are 20 million registered voters in Venezuela, but with only a 31% turn out. The opposition failed to participate in the vote. Venezuela’s opposition, Juan Guaido was the internationally recognized as Interim President of Venezuela and head of parliament by the United States, Great Britain and the European Union since 2015. Starting on January 6, 2021, the EU no longer recognizes Guaido as Interim President. The EU considers Guaido as part of a Democratic Opposition after losing his seat in Parliament in a December 2020 election. Having the title of Interim President gave Guaido funds from Western states that were confiscated from Maduro, it appears now that Guaido will no longer have those funds provided by the European Union. https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2021-03-03/venezuelas-guaido-calls-for-opposition-input-into-new-electoral-body https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/venezuela-s-maduro-claims-sweep-boycotted-election-n1250276 https://www.reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-politics-eu/eu-states-no-longer-recognise-guaido-as-venezuelas-interim-president-idUSKBN29U1A3
Probability: 1%

There is a very small chance that Maduro will cease to be president of Venezuela before April 2021. Maduro has a strong influence in Venezuela and his opposition is not in a place that can act against him at the moment. The Venezuelan economy is in crisis and there doesn't seem to be any improvements. There aren't any fruitful steps being taken to remove Maduro from power.

Opposition support has evaporated. Maduro still controls significant institutions and enjoys military support. Barring involvement from the United States, he will remain "President" of Venezuela. The Biden administration has signaled that it will communicate with Maduro on a resolution if serious steps are taken to resolve the current issues at hand with the opposition.

With only 24 days left until the deadline for this forecast, there are a number of reasons why I do not think there is a high probability that Maduro will cease to be president of Venezuela. First and foremost, Venezuela does not have any upcoming elections. Due to this, there are a limited number of ways that Maduro could be removed from his position. Various attempts to remove Maduro in recent years have failed, and Juan Guaido, political opposition to Maduro is losing support.

Unless Maduro is forced out of office, it's highly likely that he will still be president of Venezuela at the end of the month. With the military and security forces remaining loyal to him, he can sit comfortably, knowing that he is well protected. Despite more than 50 nations recognizing Guaido as the new president, Maduro will most likely remain in power. The only ways in which Maduro would cease to be in power are a coup, another nation intervenes, or he simply drops dead. Venezuelan response to Maduro has been to migrate. More than 5 million have migrated since 2014.

By looking at how long the issue of Nicolas Maduro has been going on, from the National Assembly of Venezuela declaring in 2019 that he was not the president, to him being placed on the U.S. Department of State’s Narcotics Rewards Program Targets list in March 2020, and more than 50 countries “refus[ing] to recognize Maduro as Venezuela’s head of state” in that time (which was already a year ago), I predict that it is highly unlikely that he would cease to be president in the next month (U.S. Department of State, 2020).

Maduro's government has made some notable moves to assure that Maduro will remain the president of Venezuela. These actions include boycotting elections, a sure way to remain unopposed. There was a time when the adversarial actions from the US were up in the air depending on the outcome of the 2020 presidential election- but while President Biden has referred to the Venezuelan government as "a dictatorship", it doesn't seem that a real plan to change that status has been devised. Despite US pressure, Maduro has remained in power for years and hasn't been shaken by the American change in leadership. It's doubtful that a shift significant enough to put him out of power will happen in the next month.

The Trump administration attempted to oust Maduro through heavy sanctions and even placing a bounty on Maduro's arrest. Additionally, Washington led the international effort to recognize democratic leader, Juan Guido, as Venezuela's head of state (Aljazeera, 2020).The result was a total erosion of diplomatic ties and the hope in Washington that the Maduro regime would cripple under the economic pressure. Despite the pressure, Maduro has clung to power and his officials have spoken interest in resuming diplomatic ties with the US. Maduro has also survived an attempted coup and insurgency plot while retaining the majority support of his military (O'Connor, 2020). A prominent opposition figure of the Maduro regime, Leopoldo Lopez, fled Caracas despite being unable to effectively unseat the socialist dictator (The Guardian, 2020). Analysis - Since 1950, the world has experienced 475 coups, with 236 being successful. In South America, Honduras has experienced the only successful coup since 1996 (Taylor, 2016). With the support of Russia, China, Turkey, Iran, and Cuba, Maduro is unlikely to lose power especially given the trend among his opposition to leave the country. Aside from a 'black swan' event, Maduro will remain in power.

There are a couple of reasons why it is extremely unlikely that Nicolas Maduro will cease to be president of Venezuela before April 1st, 2021. First is his widening grip over the Venezuelan government and his opposition’s, Juan Guaido's, concurrent loss of power. Though the Venezuelan parliament was previously controlled by the opposition party, that changed in December when legislative elections resulted in the Unified Socialist Party (PSUV) winning in a landslide victory, with the PSUV coalition subsequently filling 256 out of 277 seats in parliament. Now it should be clarified that these elections were boycotted by the four main opposition parties and condemned by many domestic and foreign actors; nevertheless, it resulted in Guaido losing his standing as leader of the National Assembly in January 2021. Though Guaido had been recognized by over 50 countries as interim president since the disputed re-election of Maduro in 2018, the EU stated in January that it could no longer legally recognize Guaido as interim president since he lost his position as head of the National Assembly (despite the EU not recognizing the vote itself). He is still recognized as interim president by the US and the UK, but overall, the opposition continues to lose traction as their leading politicians flee and Maduro's party gains more control (however illegitimate it may be) over the government. Secondly, Maduro has shown that sanctions placed on him and his associates, such as the oil and financial sanctions imposed by the US, are futile in trying to oust him. The EU has recently imposed sanctions on 19 more Venezuelan officials and has called for political talks in Venezuela to set up new elections, but there is very little chance that this will have an effect on Maduro's power, at least in the short term. Maduro has further cemented himself as ruling leader, exemplified that foreign efforts to oust him are futile, squashed the opposition for the most part, and has shown no intentions of surrendering or stepping down, making it extremely unlikely that he will cease to be president before April 1st. The only scenario in which he would cease to be president is if he was assassinated or there was a coup, but given that Maduro has control over Venezuelan security forces and has thwarted several assassination attempts in the past, this looks extremely unlikely as well; however, it is possible, which is why I gave a 2% chance of "yes." Overall, Maduro has managed to hold onto power for over seven years through strong opposition and international condemnation, and I, unfortunately, do not predict that changing within a month.

BLUF Forecast: 5% Yes In my assessment, Nicolas Maduro has a 5% chance of ceasing to be president of Venezuela before 01ARPIL2021. My reasoning for this comes from the protests that have taken place from 2017 to 2020 have yet to be seen in great force in 2021 (Otis, 2020). The Maduro regime has weakened the opposition party led by Juan Guaido (CIA, 2021), implementing strong restrictions on freedom of expression and the press. The corruption within the voting system in Venezuela has escalated to the point that many opposition party voters abstain from voting in national elections due to the National Election Council (CNE) being controlled by Maduro’s party and faking votes to assist Maduro (Reuters, 2021). I am leaving 5% room for Maduro to cease being president of Venezuela before 01APRIL2021 due to various environmental, security, and health factors.

It is unlikely that an event would happen before April that would challenge his rule more than it already has been. Its been said he was "on the outs" in reports from as far back as 2015...that seems to be a fairly good indication of his track record. I don't think President Biden taking office will have any effect on Maduro's status as president at least in the early days of Biden's presidency.

There does not seem to be an election process scheduled from now until April, so Nicolas Maduro can only be removed from power by an insurgency or foreign intervention. There have been struggles over the years to remove him.

Nicolas Maduro continues to weather the diplomatic international and internal pressures for him to step down as the President. Maduro survived an assassination attempt in 2018 and this likely increased his protective ring, thus reducing his risk to a second attempt. Additional Maduro is still relatively young at 58 years old and appears by all accounts to be in good health. Thus I’d say there is an extremely low probability that Maduro will cease to be President of Venezuela before 1 April 2021.
time is running out

Nicolas Maduro has a strong grip on power in Venezuela and has ruled as president since 2013. The support of the military, his party, and ally countries like Iran and Russia help to legitimize his government – despite many Western countries like the U.S. recognizing opposition leader Juan Guaido as the true interim president of Venezuela. On January 5th, 2021, following the December parliamentary elections, the governing socialist party assumed leadership of Venezuela’s congress. This was the last remaining institution in Venezuela not controlled by Maduro and his party.
Having no opposition, no scheduled elections, and previously squashing attempts to remove him by force, and placing allies in positions of power will enable him to remain in power.

First is his widening grip over the Venezuelan government and his opposition’s, Juan Guaido's, concurrent loss of power. Though the Venezuelan parliament was previously controlled by the opposition party, that changed in December when legislative elections resulted in the Unified Socialist Party (PSUV) winning in a landslide victory, with the PSUV coalition subsequently filling 256 out of 277 seats in parliament. He is still recognized as interim president by the US and the UK, but overall, the opposition continues to lose traction as their leading politicians flee and Maduro's party gains more control (however illegitimate it may be) over the government. Secondly, Maduro has shown that sanctions placed on him and his associates, such as the oil and financial sanctions imposed by the US, are futile in trying to oust him. The EU has recently imposed sanctions on 19 more Venezuelan officials and has called for political talks in Venezuela to set up new elections, but there is very little chance that this will have an effect on Maduro's power, at least in the short term. Maduro has further cemented himself as ruling leader, exemplified that foreign efforts to oust him are futile, squashed the opposition for the most part, and has shown no intentions of surrendering or stepping down, making it extremely unlikely that he will cease to be president before April 1st. The only scenario in which he would cease to be president is if he was assassinated, but given that Maduro has control over Venezuelan security forces and has thwarted several assassination attempts in the past, this looks extremely unlikely as well; however, it is possible, which is why I gave a 2% chance of "yes." Overall, Maduro has managed to hold onto power for over seven years now through strong opposition and international condemnation, and I, unfortunately, do not predict that changing within a month.

Maduro has as of late been solidifying his control and placing people he trusts in important government positions. He has successfully thwarted attempts at coups and has suppressed any form of opposition. The United States had placed an oil embargo, with the hopes that it would pressure the President to step down, yet Maduro found a way around the sanctions. He loosened his grip on the private sector allowing for an influx of money. Considering it is March 3rd, and the question asks if he will cease to be president by April 1st, there is little chance of that happening. The only instance where Maduro might "cease" to be president is if he is assanited. He has shown no intention of surrendering or stepping down from power.
didn't look likely before, even less likely with only a month to go
No planned election or major opposition
There is no planned election during this time and there is no major opposition left to take over

Maduro is in a position where there is not much opposition to his presidency both within and outside. In fact, the US has lifted partial sanctions and allowed some US firms to operate. The only major issue is the out-of-stock situation for diesel as a result of the sanctions on the oil-for-diesel exchange. Without any coup ( which failed sometime back), the chances for Maduro to remain in power is very high.

Since there no elections occurring within the timeframe provided, there are only two ways Nicolas Maduro may be removed from office – through internal coup or external interference. For external interference, the United States would be the most likely country to conduct such activity since they are the only superpower to endorse his exiled opposition, Juan Guaidó, while China and Russia back Maduro and the United Nations has resigned to accepting his authority over the country. Over the last two years there have been at least three reports of violent attempts, either supported by the US government or involving US citizens, to remove Maduro from the presidency. The most recent alleged attempt appears to have occurred in September 2020 when a U.S. citizen was arrested while possessing “a grenade launcher, a submachine gun, suspected plastic explosive material and bundles of dollars” to target oil refineries, although the United States has denied claims that this individual was working on their behalf. President Donald Trump adopted hardline policies towards Venezuela, even insinuating the possibility of invasion, and while President Joe Biden was expected to change direction, he has maintained the same course to a lesser extent – opting for targeted sanctions and humanitarian assistance. Since the Venezuelan military is also backing Maduro, it is highly unlikely an internal coup would find success within the next month. While none of this is completely possible, I would think there is less than a one in ten chance of any further attempt being made to remove Maduro and less than a one in five chance of any such attempt being successful. As a result, I find that there is a 1% chance Maduro is removed from office in the next 31 days only because I cannot go lower without saying it is impossible. Inversely, since President Biden would likely want to avoid risk of sharing the same failures as his predecessor, there is a 99% chance Maduro will retain his post in peace for at least the next 31 days.
Leaving a 1% chance for the remote possibility of stepping down or premature death.
With no election between now and then, this relies on the unlikely case he would step down (why at this point?) or death/health issue (remote possibility).

Maduro will not willfully leave office. He does not appear to be in ill health (despite COVID, Venezuela did just procure the Russian vaccine). The US will likely build a political block with the EU (contrary to Moscow-Beijing) to pressure Venezuela to hold legitimate elections, but that will take much longer than two months.
Because: - it didn't happen and there are few weeks left, - nothing in medias to my knowledge, - there is a consensus of other forecasters since a lot of weeks

Unless he suddenly dies it is very unlikely he is going to leave office.

Analyst projects that Biden is more likely to look at the possibility of joining the political parties. Notes that Venezuela is not at the top of priority lists and that the sanction strategy will be redirected. https://www.bbc.com/mundo/noticias-america-latina-55791150

https://www.vox.com/22244427/biden-trump-foreign-policy-presidency-inauguration Blinken said the US would continue to recognize Juan Guaidó as Venezuela’s interim president, a decision the Trump administration made in January 2019 as part of its effort to depose the country’s dictator, Nicolás Maduro. Blinken added that the new team would also continue to sanction Maduro and his government, only “more effectively.”

No love lost between the Maduro and Trump administrations. That being said, Antony Blinken has stated US policy will be to continue to recognize Gauido as the legitimate president. (His envoy to Washington was invited to the Inauguration.) The newest round of sanctions will continue to destroy the Venezuelan economy, but not likely have the intended effect of new elections or a revolution, as much of the population has either fled the country or does not have the means to overturn the current government.
Maduro still looks very much in charge, judging by his Twitter page. Nothing on the radar at the moment

unfortunately not, unless he gets assassinated or dies from his overweight

Country is not stable, Maduro could be requested to quit at any time, surprise probability should be always considered.

Maduro and his governing socialist party look to take over the National Assembly this week and entrench his position further - https://bit.ly/3sccl6L. As things currently stand, his position looks fairly unassailable and death looks like the only possibility of a positive outcome for this question.

The European Union just dropped recognition of opposition President Juan Guaido (while the U.S. still recognizes him), after the National Assembly's mandate for the government was reached on Tuesday. Maduro continues to consolidate power and is unlikely to relinquish it any time soon. https://www.ft.com/content/aa372f3a-a1ac-41da-848a-46355fc3ec4f https://ge.usembassy.gov/the-united-states-continues-to-recognize-interim-president-guaido-and-the-last-democratically-elected-national-assembly-in-venezuela/
A surprise may always happens. Conditions are worse day after day. Notifications would not be anticipated for this event.

Questions I am considering: 1) What would the causal chain of events look like that would lead to Maduro ceasing to be president by the question deadline? 2) Is his regime stable? Are there indicators of instability? 3) Are there any actors (individual or countries) that can in any way individually or when combined cause a viable threat to his continuation in the role of president?
Maduro continues to consolidate his position - https://bit.ly/2X0NQe7 - and will son be able to 'eliminate' all opposition.
@bobrown @Wildwood2000

He's solid through April. Despite terrible economy, isolation etc, he has support of military, "won" parliamentary elections, and oppo is divided. In 2021, Biden plan seems to be build int'l coalitions retool sanctions with humanitarian exceptions, and possibly negotiate for a real election. Also as vaccine becomes available & world economies open, oil demand and prices are likely to increase, which will further cement his economic position.

With the opposition losing in the recent legislative elections, Maduro's increasing grip on everything, and that it will take the Biden administration months to iron out an executable Venezuela strategy, my forecast remains close enough to 0% (e.g. death, coup are di minimus probabilities) to call it a 0%.
Always have to account for a coup, but he has a hammerlock on his country. Cuba and Russia won't allow him to fall.
Updating with the same forecast.
The opposition is divided. After the latest elections Maduro has consolidated his grip on power. The US will focus its attention elsewhere.
Adjusting to wisdom of the crowd given no new information that I can find to warrant a lower percentage.
Nothing in terms of social unrest, political instability or political challenges being made apparent in any media I can find despite the rigged vote.

I don't know how I feel about this. Maduro continues to consolidate power, and the opposition isn't strong enough to stop him, or gain ground. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/12/19/venezuela-to-shut-all-powerful-legislative-assembly
Short time frame and seems like his position is fairly secure.

With control of the National Assembly, the Socialist Party will win this Sunday's election. Maduro will remain president at least throughout the first half of 2021 as Venezuelans will look to him to lead the countrywide rollout of the COVID-19 vaccnine.
still believe it is unlikely as a scenario. Amid the COVID-19 pandemic, Maduro does not constitute a priority for the incoming Biden administration

I cannot see any way this becomes a priority for the incoming biden administration in the time allotted, and assume us buy-in is necessary for his removal (absent natural causes, indie assassination attempt, etc.)

Same forecast but updating based on last week's election results. 0% he'd leave office or be removed, but keeping 5% on the board as long as COVID-19 is a plausible threat. Vaccine roll out news will likely cause my next move (Maduro's son reportedly has already received both doses)

Russia supplying vaccines to Maduro won't hurt him, it's the cold war all over again with the countries backing Maduro lining up vs those in support of Guadio https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Responses_to_the_Venezuelan_presidential_crisis
updating based on the results of recent vote. thanks @bh4eh
Maduro seems to be in his strongest position ever. As long as the military supports him he will stay. I don't see him loosing military support in the short term.

The only realist way Maduro will not be president in this timeline is if he dies. His control over the Army and the political system is largely absolute, and his backers will continue to back him, if only in an attempt to create problems for the US. President elect Biden is going to have other priorities in his first 100 days, and there is unlikely to be much interest in fomenting a crisis in Latin America in the first months of his presidency. Maduro is likely safe until late 2021 at the earliest.
He will hold onto power by any means necessary, including cheating, lying, murder. intimidation and bribery. International pressure and bad press doesn't affect these people. .

The man is not leaving except in handcuffs or on a stretcher. If he gets COVID or has other health issues, there is a fair chance he doesn't survive given his health. But Cuba, Iran, China & Russia will continue to prop him up for the foreseeable future so he isn't going anywhere any time soon. He's packed the courts, neutered the legislature, pushed his opponents out of office and runs things with an iron fist. And that fist - the military - depends on him so they won't turn on him.

President Maduro looks entrenched https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/official-maduro-allies-win-91-seats-venezuela-vote-74652316 https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/12/09/biden-foreign-policy-venezuela-maduro/

Maduro's Socialist Party now controls 67% of the national assembly, so it's unlikely he'll go out that way. The opposition (who boycotted the election) does not have a great chance of overturning the current election results with a justice system that isn't sympathetic to their cause. It's highly unlikely that the Trump administration would mount an operation to dislodge Maduro, and even more unlikely that Biden's foreign policy for Venezuela would forcibly remove the dictator without first using diplomatic measures. https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/12/7/venezuelan-president-maduro-claims-sweep-of-boycotted-election https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2020/12/09/biden-foreign-policy-venezuela-maduro/ https://www.britannica.com/biography/Nicolas-Maduro
Maduro's party just won 91% of the vote in parliament after the opposition boycotted, his grip on power seems rock solid and no change likely before 1 April

The debate over presidency has continued since the beginning of 2019. And while the dire economic conditions (hyperinflation) and global support for Guaido is likely to put Maduro under a lot of pressure, I do not expect the process to resolve within one quarter of 2021. Maduro is also likely contemplating dollarization of the economy to combat hyperinflation- a move that is supported by the local population and could potentially buy him some time. Moreover, President elect Biden could choose to take a more diplomatic stance with Maduro than Trump did and choose to negotiate with him, further delaying any change in power.

Maduro's grip on power just tightened with his alliance winning the majority in the National Assembly, an overdetermined success given the opposition's boycott of the elections (based on protests of illegitimacy of elections). Maduro maintains the support of the military and formally controls the major institutions of power. Given the participation rate in this legislative election (31%), it appears that (in addition to the boycott) the voters do not believe taking part in the political process is worth their time, so its unlikely the opposition will marshal the additional support they need to continue to challenge Maduro. I think it unlikely Biden will take up the issue of election legitimacy in Venezuela; it's the problem of living in a glass house (those who live in one, should not throw stones).
Chance for an event that removes him seems very low.
Crowd Sourced.

It failed once, why should it be retry soon? Biden seem to be very cautious when it's about military operation (Ben Laden); 3 - More than 5 million venezuelans have left the country, it,s like 5 millions of person who think there will not be change sooner https://www.dw.com/en/displaced-oil-and-ruin-the-exodus-of-venezuela/av-52011198 4 - Latest election show us that nothing can occur from an election https://elpais.com/internacional/2020-12-07/las-elecciones-parlamentarias-evidencian-la-fractura-en-venezuela.html 5- With allies countries like Russia, China or Cuba, Nicolas Maduro seem to be in a more better position than other country leaders like Assad who is still there for a long time now.
Maduro remains in power, backed by the Venezuelan military as well as key allies Cuba, Russia, China, Turkey, and Iran. What can change about such a situation in three months?

https://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/venezuelans-wait-results-boycotted-congress-vote-74577392 Opposition boycotted elections this week, so Maduro increased his control over the government. on the flip side only 31% of eligible Venezuelans voted and Gauido is running a grassroots referendum this week, it ends Saturday. If it shows strong support then maybe there is a way forward for the opposition. Otherwise it looks like Maduro will stay in place.
He controls too much of the apparatus of the state.

There has been increased negative attention to the country's election integrity with statements by Mike Pompeo and op-eds in major newspapers. The election itself increases Maduro's grip on the country, or at least delays any action. Biden is unlikely to make this a top priority, so sufficient pressure from the US to enact change by April 1 seems unlikely.
Despite the short timeframe, it is not a totally impossible scenario. In particular, Biden may exercise pressure on Maduro

Authoritarian leaders in South American are overthrown fairly infrequently. Similarly, I think it is a good axiom that authoritarian leader generally do no willingly step down from power unless forced. This sets my baseline probability fairly low that Maduro will cease being president of Venezuela before April 2021. However, a new Biden administration might increase pressure on Maduro in way the Trump administration had not.

The victory of Maduro's side in the election, even if rigged, strengthens his position in the short term. Add to this the continued backing of the military and he seems relatively secure for now. Perhaps the opposition can arouse more widespread protests and upheaval but this also seems unlikely to work unless it sways the military. The group of nearly 60 states that recognize Guiado as the legitimate ruler now is in a quandary...will they apply greater international pressure claiming the election was illegitimate? Perhaps, but again seems likely to have the power to oust Maduro in the next 4 1/2 months.
Lowering the probability based on recent National Assembly election outcome.

Maduro's coalition won a majority in Sunday's National Assembly election. The polls were probably rigged, but I don't think that will matter barring an unlikely social uprising. Guido's legitimacy, such as it is, will be diminished when the new National Assembly speaker is selected in January. The military has shown no indication of breaking with Maduro despite opportunity and inducements. The opposition has called for consultations to discuss options next week. Unless they can stir the masses to action, Maduro's power seems relatively secure.

~35% voter turnout, with ~70% of them for Maduro highlights just how disengaged the population is from politics right now. The majority not even bothering to protest vote (18% of the votes were for an opposition).
Elections are over, it will be difficult for anyone to remove him from power in such a short time frame.
Biden will not push regime change and neither will his national security team

The debate over presidency has continued since the beginning of 2019. And while the dire economic conditions (hyperinflation) and global support for Guaido is likely to put Maduro under a lot of pressure, I do not expect the process to resolve within one quarter of 2021. Maduro is also likely contemplating dollarization of the economy to combat hyperinflation- a move that is supported by the local population and could potentially buy him some time. Moreover, President elect Biden could choose to take a more diplomatic stance with Maduro than Trump did and choose to negotiate with him, further delaying any change in power.
His regime is on pretty weak footing given the state of the economy and he will be pushed out at some point in time - but it could take well past April 1st.

Maduro has learnt the lesson of other dictators in that retaining the loyalty of the elite and the armed forces is the most effective method of staying in power unless external forces invade.
